Saturday, December 22, 2007, 2:30 pm Film at Remis Auditourium - MFA Boston

The Yacoubian Building by Marwan Hamed (Egypt, 2006, 172 min.). The most expensive Egyptian film ever made, The Yacoubian Building is a sprawling, star-studded epic that spans the social stratosphere of contemporary Cairo. In three fast-moving hours, the film dramatizes such issues as adultery, political corruption, terrorism, and homosexuality. Based on Alaa Al Aswani?s novel, first-time director Marwan Hamed crafts a gripping drama set in a downtown Cairo apartment building: an aging playboy represents a vanishing world of gentility, a French singer pines for his former love, and a pretty young girl is disillusioned. The growing influence of Islam is dramatized through two controversial storylines: the doorman?s son, frustrated in his attempts to move up in society, turns to religious fanaticism and ends up training for jihad in a desert camp, while the religious piety of a businessman who has risen from a shoeshine boy is exposed as a sham that hides only self-interest. Description adapted from the Tribeca Film Festival 2006. In Arabic with English subtitles.

It has limited review on RottenTomatoes http://www.rottentoma...
but it is batting 100%

Afterwards we'll head up to the Shawarma restaurant on Huntington to discuss the movie.
